fact: 1 in 200 cats suffer from asthma
75% of cats that go missing in the U.S. are returned safely
A cat can jump 7 times as high as it is tall
Cats can spend five or more hours a day grooming themselves
A cat cannot see directly under its nose
A cat has a total of 24 whiskers, 4 rows of whiskers on each side. The upper two rows can move independently of the bottom two rows
A cat has been mayor of Talkeetna, Alaska, for the past 20 years. His name is Stubbs
A cat has detected their human's breast cancer
A cat has more bones than a human; humans have 206, but the cat has 230 (some sources list 245 bones, and state that bones may fuse together as the cat ages)
A cat has two vocal chords, yet can make over 100 sounds
A cat nicknamed “Unsinkable Sam” survived the sinking of three separate ships during WWII
A cat ran for mayor of Mexico City in 2013
A cat sees about 6 times better than a human at night because they have a layer of extra reflecting cells which absorb light
The whiskers of a cat are capable of registering very small changes in air pressure
A cat will spend nearly 30% of their life grooming themselves
A cat will tremble or shiver when it is in extreme pain
A cat's jaw has only up and down motion; it does not have any lateral, side to side motion, like dogs and humans
A cat's meow is usually not directed at another cat, but at a human. To communicate with other cats, they will usually hiss, purr, and spit
A cat's carbon footprint is similar to that of a VW Bug, whereas a dog’s is more like a Hummer
A cat's cerebral cortex (the part of the brain in charge of cognitive information processing) has 300 million neurons, compared with a dog’s 160 million
A cat's nose is ridged with a unique pattern, just like a human fingerprint
A cat's sense of smell is approximately 14 times greater than that of a human
A domestic cat can sprint at about 31 miles per hour
A female Amur leopard gives birth to between one to four cubs in each litter
A female cat will be pregnant for approximately 9 weeks (or between 62 and 65 days) from conception to delivery
A form of AIDS exists in cats
A group of cats is called a clowder
A group of kittens is called a kindle
A happy cat holds their tail high and steady
A healthy cat has a temperature between 100.4 and 102.2 degrees Farenheit, or 38 and 39 degrees Celcius
A normal house cat (not a chubby one) is faster than Usain Bolt
A kitten will typically weigh about 3 ounces at birth. The typical male housecat will weigh between 7 and 9 pounds, slightly less for female housecats
A thought to be mutated kitten with green fur was discovered in Denmark in 1995. Scientists later found out it was from high copper levels in the water supply
A male cat is called a “Tom” and a female cat is called a “Queen” or a “Molly”
A physicist made his cat the co-author of his scientific paper to avoid replacing “we” with “I” throughout his paper
A female cat can begin mating when they are between 5 and 9 months old
A sexually-active feral tom-cat “owns” an area of about three square miles and “sprays” to mark his territory with strong smelling urine
A tiger's stripes are like fingerprints, no two tigers have the same pattern
Abraham Lincoln kept four cats in the White House
According to the Association for Pet Obesity Prevention (APOP), about 50 million of American cats are overweight
All cats have three sets of long hairs that are sensitive to pressure - whiskers, eyebrows,and the hairs between their paw pads
All cats need taurine in their diet to avoid blindness. Cats must also have fat in their diet as they are unable to produce it on their own
*All cats are good natural hunters (*we know which ones aren't)
Almost 10% of a cat's bones are in its tail, and the tail is used to maintain balance
Although it is known to be the “tailless cat”, the Manx can be born with a stub or a short tail
Among many other diseases, cats can suffer from anorexia, senility, feline AIDS, and acne.
An adult lion's roar can be heard up to five miles (eight kilometers) away
Ancient Egyptian family members shaved their eyebrows in mourning when the family cat died
Around the world, cats take a break to nap - a catnap - 425 million times a day
Baking chocolate is the most dangerous chocolate to your cat
Black cats are bad luck in the United States, but they are good luck in the United Kingdom and Australia
Blue-eyed, pure white cats are frequently deaf
Bobtails are known to have notably short tails - about half or a third the size of the average house cat
Both humans and cats have identical regions in the brain responsible for emotion
British cat owners spend roughly 550 million pounds ($675 million dollars) yearly on cat food
Cat bites are more likely to become infected than dog bites, so be nice to your cat!
Cat families usually play best in even numbers. Cats and kittens should be acquired in pairs whenever possible
Cat owners are 17% more likely to have a graduate degree
Cat owners who are male tend to be luckier in love, as they are perceived as more sensitive
Cat people are 25% likely to pick George Harrison as their favorite Beatle
Cat people are also 11% more likely to be introverted. But cat people are more open to new experiences than typical “dog people”
Cat's back claws aren't as sharp as the claws on their front paws
Cat's urine will glow under a black light. Go try this at home
Cats actually have dreams, just like us. They start dreaming when they reach a week old
Cats are believed to be responsible for the extinction of several species of animals
Cats are more likely to survive a higher fall because they have more time to prepare their body and decelerate
Cats are now Britain's favourite pet: there are 7.7 million cats as opposed to 6.6 million dogs
Cats are really cool
Cats are subject to “whisker stress” where they may not like pressure on their whiskers while they eat or drink
Cats are such picky eaters because they are naturally driven to eat foods with a preferred ratio of protein to fat: 1 to 0.4
Cats are susceptible to more than 250 hereditary disorders, and many of them are similar to diseases that humans get
Cats can move their ears separately
Cats can be taught to walk on a leash, but a lot of time and patience is required to teach them. It is easier for younger cats to learn this cool trick
Cats can bite
Cats can change their meow to manipulate a human. For example, they often imitate a human baby when they need food
Cats can drink salt water and survive. They have crazy kidneys that filter out the salt from the water to re-hydrate themselves
Cats can get tapeworms from eating fleas. These worms live inside the cat forever, or until they are removed with medication
Cats can judge within 3 inches the precise location of a sound being made 1 yard away
Cats can move their ears 180 degrees
Cats can pick up on your tone of voice, so sweet-talking to your cat has more of an impact than you think
Cats can swallow and digest their food without chewing it
Cats can't taste sweetness
Cats come back to full alertness from a sleepy state faster than any other creature
Cats do not think that they are little people. They think that we are big cats. This influences their behavior in many ways
Cats eat grass to aid their digestion and to help them get rid of any fur in their stomachs
Cats have 1,000 times more data storage than an iPad
Cats have 30 vertebrae (humans have 33 vertebrae during early development; 26 after the sacral and coccygeal regions fuse)
Cats have 32 muscles that control the outer ear while humans have only 6
Cats have a longer-term memory than dogs, especially when they learn by actually doing rather than simply seeing
Cats have a lower social IQ than dogs, but cats can solve more difficult cognitive problems when they feel like it
Cats have a strong aversion to anything citrus
Cats have individual preferences for scratching surfaces and angles. Some are horizontal scratchers while others exercise their claws vertically
Cats have inferior daytime sight, but during the night they need seven times less light than humans to see
Cats have the cognitive ability to sense a human's feelings and overall mood
Cats have the largest eyes of any mammal
Cats have the skillset that makes them able to learn how to use a toilet
Cats have three eyelids
Cats knead with their paws when they are happy
Cats lap liquid from the underside of their tongue, not from the top
Cats lick themselves to get your scent off. Don't be stinky
Cats lived with soldiers in trenches during World War I, where they killed and usually ate mice
Cats make more than 100 different sounds whereas dogs make only around 10
Cats may paw water to create ripples, which makes the water more interesting and fun
Cats only sweat through their foot pads
Cats place themselves in an umbrella position, much like a skydiver, to slow down a fall
Cats prefer their food at room temperature—not too hot, not too cold, but just right
Cats respond most readily to names that end in an “ee” sound
Cats share 95.6% of their DNA with tigers
Cats sleep 70% of their lives
Cats use their whiskers to detect if they can fit through a space
Cats walk on their toes
Cats who eat too much tuna can become addicted, which can actually cause a Vitamin E deficiency
Cats who fall five stories have a 90 percent survival rate
Cats with long, lean bodies are more likely to be outgoing, and more protective and vocal than those with a stocky build
Cats would rather starve themselves than eat something they don't like
Cats, especially older cats, may get cancer. Many times this disease can be treated successfully
Cats, just like people, are subject to asthma. Dust, smoke, and other forms of air pullution in your cat's environment can be sources of irritation
Cats' hearing stops at 65 khz (kilohertz); humans' hearing stops at 20 khz
Cats' self-cleaning can help them cool off, stimulate circulation, comfort them, and keep them clean of odors that might attract predators
Caution during Christmas; the Poinsettia flower may be festive, but they’re poisonous to cats
You can get Toxoplasmosis from cleaning the litter box of an infected cat. If pregnant, a baby can be born with cerebral palsy, seizures, or mental retardation
Collectively, kittens yawn about 200 million time per hour all around the world
Contrary to popular belief, the cat is a social animal. A pet cat will respond and answer to speech, and seems to (usually) enjoy human companionship
Declawing a cat is the same as cutting a human's fingers off at the knuckle. There are several alternatives to a complete declawing!!
Declawing cats is legal in most U.S. states but banned in at least 22 countries including Germany, Finland, Switzerland, Australia, New Zealand and Japan.
Despite appearing like a wild cat, the Ocicat does not have an ounce of wild blood.
Disneyland owns about 200 cats. Every night, the cats are released in the park to hunt down all the little Mickeys and Minnies for cat snacks
Domestic cats purr both when inhaling and when exhaling
Each side of a cat's face has about 12 whiskers
Edward Lear, author of “The Owl and the Pussycat”, built a clone of his previous residence so that his much-loved tabby, Foss, would immediately feel at home
Egyptian's had elaborate memorials that included mummifying the cat and either burying it in a family tomb or pet cemetery
80% percent of cats in the U.S. are spayed or neutered
Even healthy cats can exhibit symptoms of illness, including vomiting or a decreased appetite, if there is a change in their routines
1 in 4 pregnant cats carries kittens fathered by more than one mate. A fertile female may mate with several tom-cats, which fertilize different eggs each time
Every single domesticated cat could be traced back to one of five African wild cats from 8000 BC
Evidence suggests domesticated cats have been around since 3600 BC, 2,000 years before Egypt's pharaohs
Female cats are “polyestrous”, which means they may have many heat periods over the course of a year
A heat period lasts about 4 to 7 days if a female cat is bred; if she is not, the heat period lasts longer and recurs at regular intervals
Female cats are typically right-pawed while male cats are typically left-pawed
Florence Nightingale, the founder of modern nursing, owned more than 60 cats in her lifetime
Humans greet each other by shaking hands; cats greet one another by touching their noses together
If a cat is frightened, put your hand over its eyes and forehead, or let them bury their head in your armpit to help calm them
If a cat is frightened, the hair stands up fairly evenly all over the body
When the cat is threatened or is ready to attack, the hair stands up only in a narrow band along the spine and tail
If your cat snores or rolls over on his back to expose its belly, it means that it trusts you
If your cat's eyes are closed, it's not necessarily because it is tired. A sign of closed eyes means your cat is happy or pleased
In 2009, an accused Florida man said his cat downloaded child porn, not him
In an average year, cat owners in the United States spend over $2 billion on cat food
In ancient Egypt, killing a cat was a crime punishable by death
In homes with more than one cat, it is best to have cats of the opposite sex. They tend to be better housemates
In just 7 years, one un-spayed female cat and one un-neutered male cat and their offspring can result in 420,000 kittens
In Korea and Japan, there is a Cat Cafe where you can go to drink coffee and hang out with cats for hours
In multi-pet households, cats are able to get along well with dogs if they're introduced when the cat is under 6 months old and the dog is under one year old
In one litter of kittens, there could be multiple “father” cats
In one stride, a cheetah can cover 23 to 26 feet (7 to 8 meters)
In the 1960s, the CIA turned a cat into a spy by implanting a microphone and transmitter in its head. Sadly, the cat got hit by a taxi on its first mission
In the wild, lions live for an average of 12 years and up to 16 years. They live up to 25 years in captivity
In tigers and house cats, the middle of the tongue is covered in backward-pointing spines, used for breaking off and gripping meat
Isaac Newton invented the cat flap after his own cat, Spithead, kept opening the door and spoiling his light experiments
It is estimated that cats can make over 60 different sounds
It may take up to 2 weeks for a kitten to be able to hear well. Their eyes usually open between 7 and 10 days, but sometimes it happens in as little as 2 days
Julius Ceasar, Henri II, Charles XI, and Napoleon were all afraid of cats
Kittens who are taken along on short, trouble-free car trips to town, tend to make good passengers when they get older
Thanks to the help of their eyes and special balance organs in their inner ear, cats can straighten themselves in the air and land upright on the ground
Lions are the only cats that live in groups, called prides. Every female within the pride is usually related
Maine Coons are the most massive breed of house cats. They can weigh up to around 24 pounds
Many cats cannot properly digest cow's milk. Milk and dairy products may give some cats diarrhea
Miacis, the primitive ancestor of cats, was a small, tree-living creature of the late Eocene period, some 45 to 50 million years ago
More than 86,000 people are injured by tripping over their cats and dogs every year in the USA
Most cat litters contain four to six kittens
Most cats don't have eyelashes
Most cats don't like water because their coats do not insulate them well enough
Most cats killed on the road are un-neutered toms, as they are more likely to roam further afield and cross busy roads
Most cats will eat 7 to 20 small meals a day
Most kittens are born with blue eyes, which then turn color with age
Neutering a male cat will almost always stop him from spraying, fighting with other males over females, likely lengthen his life, and improve its quality
Never give your cat aspirin unless specifically prescribed by your veterinarian; it can be fatal. Never ever give Tylenol to a cat
Keep anti-freeze away from all animals, such as cats. It is sweet and enticing, but deadly poison.
Of all the species of cats, the domestic cat is the only species able to hold its tail vertically while walking
All species of wild cats hold their tail horizontally or tucked between their legs while walking, unlike house cats
On average, a cat will sleep for up to 16 hours a day
On September 6, 1950, a 4 month old kitten belonging to Josephine Aufdenblatten followed a group of climbers to the top of the 14,691 ft Matterhorn in the Alps
One legend claims that cats were created when a lion on Noah’s Ark sneezed and two kittens came out
One study found neutered male cats live 62% longer than unneutered ones
One un-neutered female cat can, in five years, be responsible for over 20,000 descendants
Female cats can have their first litter as young as six months and can have up to three litters each year with five or six kittens in each litter
Only 11.5% of people consider themselves “cat people”
Only 24% of cats who enter animal shelters are adopted
Original kitty litter was made out of sand but it was replaced by more absorbent clay in 1948
Owning a cat can reduce the risk of stroke and heart attack by 33%
Phoenician cargo ships are thought to have brought the first domesticated cats to Europe in about 900 BC
Polydactyl cats are also referred to as “Hemingway cats” because the author was so fond of them
Purring does not always indicate that a cat is happy and healthy, some cats will purr loudly when they are terrified or in pain.
Ragdoll cats live up to their name; they will literally go limp, with relaxed muscles, when lifted by a human
Research has shown that domestic cats never forgive. They fail to show signs of reconciliation like other animals do
Scientists have created glow-in-the-dark cats by inserting the jellyfish protein that codes for bioluminescence into their genome
Senior cats start to experience something like human dementia or Alzheimer’s when they reach an old age, usually around 8 years
Siamese kittens are born white because of the heat inside the mother's uterus before birth. This heat keeps the kittens' hair from darkening on the points
Some cats have been documented to have a longevity of 34 years
Some cats like mice
Some cats may prefer licking their paws to drinking out of a water bowl if they don't like the shape of the water bowl
Some common houseplants poisonous to cats include: English Ivy, iris, mistletoe, philodendron, and yew
Some notable people who disliked cats: Napoleon Bonaparte, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Hitler
Sometimes called the Canadian Hairless, the Sphynx breed has been around since 1966
Spaying a female before her first or second heat will greatly reduce the threat of mammary cancer and uterine disease
A female cat does not need to have at least 1 litter to be healthy
A cat named “Dusty” gave birth to 420 documented kittens in her lifetime
A cat named “Kitty” gave birth to 2 kittens at the age of 30, having given birth to a documented 218 kittens in her lifetime
The allergen in cats is often related to their scent glands, in which case, allergic people should tolerate spayed female cats the best
Cats have scent glands on their faces and at the base of their tails. Entire male cats generate the most scent
Tests done by the Musuem of Natural History conclude that while a dog's memory lasts about 5 minutes, a cat's recall can last as long as 16 hours
The ancestor of all domestic cats is the African Wild Cat, which still exists today
The ancient Egyptians were the first civilization to realize the cat's potential as a vermin hunter, and tamed cats to protect their corn supplies
The average cat food meal is the equivalent to about five mice
The average lifespan of an outdoor-only cat is about 3 to 5 years while an indoor-only cat can live 16 years or longer
A cat's collarbone does not connect with other bones, but is buried in muscles of the shoulder region; they can fit through any opening the size of their head
The cat's front paw has 5 toes and the back paws have 4. Cats born with 6 or 7 front toes and extra back toes are called polydactl
The color of the points in Siamese cats is heat related. Cool areas are darker
The death rate for cats falling from a 2 to 6-story building is much higher than falling from a 7 to 32-story building
You can learn about your cat's present state of mind by observing the posture of its tail
The first cat in space was French. She was named Felicette, or “Astrocat.” She survived the trip
The first cat show was in 1871 at the Crystal Palace in London
The first cloned cat was called “CC”, short for “Carbon Copy”
The first true cats came into existence about 12 million years ago and were the Proailurus
The Guinness World Records stopped awarding the fattest cats or any other animal to discourage deliberate overfeeding
The heaviest domestic cat on record is 46 lb 15.2 oz (21.297 kilograms)
The largest litter of kittens produced 19 kittens
The life expectancy of cats has nearly doubled since 1930 - from 8 to 16 years
The Maine Coone is the only native American long haired breed
The majority of the cats enjoyed being pet. Ones that don't allow it are likely stressed
The name “jaguar” comes from a Native American word meaning “he who kills with one leap”
The oldest cat video on YouTube dates back to 1894
The Pilgrims were the first to introduce cats to North America as pest controllers
The smallest breed of domestic cat is the Singapura or “Drain Cat” of Singapore. Adult females weigh in at an average of 4lbs
Leopards are the strongest climber among big cats, and can carry prey twice its weight up a tree
The technical term for “hairball” is “bezoar”
The two outer layers of cat's hair are called, respectively, the guard hair and the awn hair
The way you treat kittens in the early stages of it's life will render it's personality traits later in life
The world's smallest cat is called “Tinker Toy” and he's just 2.75 inches (7 cm) tall
The world's largest cat measured 48.5 inches long
The world’s richest cat is worth $13 million after his human passed away and left her fortune to him
There are 45 Hemingway cats living at the author's former home in Key West, Florida
There are cats who have survived falls from over 32 stories (320 meters) onto concrete
There is a species of cat smaller than the average housecat. It is native to Africa and is called the Black-footed cat, with a max weight at 5.5 pounds
There's a theater in Russia where all the actors are cats
Today there are about 100 distinct breeds of the domestic cat
25% of cat owners use a blow drier on their cats after bathing
Unlike humans, cats do not need to blink their eyes on a regular basis to keep their eyes lubricated
Unlike most other cats, the Turkish Van breed has a water-resistant coat and enjoys being in water
When a cats rubs up against you, the cat is marking you with it's scent claiming ownership
When asked if her husband had any hobbies, Mary Todd Lincoln is said to have replied "cats
When cats grimace, they are usually “taste-scenting.” They have an extra organ that, with some breathing control, allows the cats to taste-sense the air
When cats leave their poop uncovered, it is a sign of aggression to let you know they don’t fear you
When well treated, a cat can live twenty or more years but the average life span of a domestic cat is 14 years
When your cat brings home a dead mouse or bird, it may do so to show you that you are inferior at hunting
You check your cats pulse on the inside of the back thigh, where the leg joins to the body. Normal heart rate for cats is 110-170 beats per minute
Your cat recognizes your voice but just acts too cool to care (probably because they are)
Cats are scared of snails
Cats can drink seawater
Some cats have thumbs
The furry tufts on the inside of cats’ ears are called “ear furnishings”
Cats can’t see directly below their noses
Nikola Tesla was inspired to investigate electricity after his cat, Macak, gave him a static shock
Kittens sleep a lot because their bodies release a growth hormone only when they’re asleep
Cats have a third eyelid called a “haw”. It’s generally only visible when they’re unwell
In the original Italian version of Cinderella, the benevolent fairy godmother figure was a cat
Cats can find their way home through “psi-travelling”. Experts think they navigate via the angle of sunlight, or magnetised brain cells that act like compasses
The more you talk to your cat, the more it will talk to you
Cats aren’t the only animals that purr; squirrels, lemurs, elephants, and even gorillas purr too
If your cat’s tail is vibrating, it's excited to see you
According to a Cornell University study, between 65 to 85 percent of white cats that have blue eyes are hearing impaired
It is unknown how cats purr. Scientists know it involves the larynx and diaphragm muscles but they're not sure exactly how those muscles work together
A dying body gives off a scent that cats are particularly sensitive to
In 1837, Belgium hired 37 cats as mail carriers. Not surprisingly, it did not work
Cats like olives because olives have a similar chemical compound in them to catnip
Nicolas Cage's cat once accidentally ate a bunch of the actor's hallucinogenic mushrooms, so Cage decided the two would trip together
Calico cats are nearly always female
Orange cats are usually male
Cats aren't exactly nocturnal. They're considered “crepuscular”, so they typically have a schedule where they're most active at the same dawn and dusk hours
Cats kill around 2.4 million birds a year
